div1.p: Seguin reports on the use of Noguchi serum and vaccine in French West Africa, and discusses its prophylactic value.

div1.head: English translation [from French] of a report extract: Report on the epidemic [sic.] of yellow fever in Segou from October to November, 1922, by [s.n.] Seguin, February 12, 1923 (See French original.)
div1.p:
(COPY)
7-3-1923
VS
Translated from the French.
(Enclosed with a letter from the Governor General
on French West Africa, dated June 6, 1923.)
************
Extract from a report by Dr. Seguin on the use of the Noguchi
serum and vaccine during the Segou epidemic in French West
Africa (Sudan) in 1922.
Bamako, Feb. 12, 1923. Report on the spidemic of yellow fever in Segou
from October to November, 1922.

3) The first parcel of serum and vaccine reached Segou
on November 9, where the last European to die had been Monsieur
X... of the Niger Mission, on October 31. A first injection of
2 cc. of vaccine was given to the inhabitants of Segou, about 40 in
number, on November 10. The second injection was given on the
14th, or four days later.

It also seemed necessary to vaccinate the nine members of
the Niger Mission, of whom six were in Niamina and three in
Sansanding. These vaccinations were made by Major Alexandre,
at whose disposal the Governor of the Sudan placed a steamer,
and they were completed on November 20.

A Liberian in the service of Dr. Y...., a member of the
Niger Mission, was the last to die of yellow fever, on November
9, the same day that the first parcel of vaccine was leaving
Bamako. This death occurred in Segou.

It was therefore impossible to give this Liberian
either serum or vaccine. Since there has been no further case
of yellow fever in Segou, no trial of the Noguchi serum has been
made. I can thus have no opinion as to the value of the serum.
__________________________________________________
(1) This serum and vaccine were part of the stock that
Dr. Bauvallet had on hand.
2.
having had no patients on whom to try it.

As to the prophylactic value of the vaccine, the con-
ditions under which it was used do not permit of any definite
conclusions. The vaccine may have helped to destroy the small
focus of yellow fever that existed in Segou, but it would not be
scientific to affirm it. In fact, 11 days had already gone by
since the last European death definitely due to yellow fever when
the vaccine was first injected, and thirteen or fourteen days had
passed since quarters inhabited by the preceding patients had been
abandoned and disinfected, first by burning tobacco leaves and
then by the use of sulphur.

In addition to this, the season was already advanced and
the mosquitoes had become very rare. All these reasons make it
impossible to draw any conclusions as to the value of the vaccine
from the anti-yellow-fever vaccination practiced in Segou.
